perturbation.original_text: 9.3 To remunerate HGF on the basis of thirty percent (30%) of net Company income basis on an annual basis commencing 12 months after the first full 12-month revenue period.

perturbation.original_text: 15.1 The Company will prepare quarterly statements for review by the Parties, released on the 15th day of each subsequent quarter.
perturbation.changed_text: 15.1 The Company will prepare annual statements for review by the Parties, released on the 15th day of the second subsequent year.
perturbation.explanation: This changes the frequency of financial reporting from quarterly to annually, delaying the release of these statements to the 15th day of the second subsequent year. Many jurisdictions mandate more frequent financial reporting for businesses, especially joint ventures. Delaying financial reporting for over a year could violate regulations requiring regular and transparent financial disclosures to stakeholders. This change introduces a delay that contradicts standard accounting practices and possibly regulations concerning the frequency of financial reporting.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of laws mandating regular financial reporting and transparency.

perturbation.original_text: 17.1 All company records will be kept for a minimum of five (5) years unless otherwise required by federal or provincial law.
perturbation.changed_text: 17.1 All company records will be kept for a minimum of two (2) years unless otherwise required by federal or provincial law.
perturbation.explanation: The change reduces the minimum record retention period from five years to two years. Many federal and provincial laws (both in the US and Canada) require businesses to maintain records for longer periods for tax, audit, and compliance purposes. Reducing the retention period could lead to non-compliance with these legal requirements.
